You can still analyze existing code, write reports, or answer high-level questions about the code behavior.\n</system-reminder>\n"}]},"parent_tool_use_id":null,"session_id":"8dc8078d-b0ac-4b4d-8dec-03c015ace4f4","uuid":"b3324e9b-5c7e-4354-b06b-69418eebebc6"}
{"type":"user","message":{"role":"user","content":[{"tool_use_id":"toolu_011GqQrJHbf7ycdw66mc3axq","type":"tool_result","content":"     1â†’# nanoBragg PyTorch Testing Strategy\n     2â†’\n     3â†’**Version:** 1.1  \n     4â†’**Date:** 2024-07-25  \n     5â†’**Owner:** [Your Name/Team]\n     6â†’\n     7â†’## 1. Introduction & Philosophy\n     8â†’\n     9â†’This document outlines the comprehensive testing strategy for the PyTorch implementation of nanoBragg. The primary goal is to ensure that the new application is a correct, verifiable, and trustworthy scientific tool.\n    10â†’Our testing philosophy is a three-tiered hybrid approach, designed to build confidence layer by layer:\n    11â†’\n    12â†’1. **Tier 1: Translation Correctness:** We first prove that the PyTorch code is a faithful, numerically precise reimplementation of the original C code's physical model. The C code is treated as the \"ground truth\" specification.\n    13â†’2. **Tier 2: Gradient Correctness:** We then prove that the new differentiable capabilities are mathematically sound.\n    14â†’3. **Tier 3: Scientific Validation:** Finally, we validate the model against objective physical principles.\n    15â†’\n    16â†’All tests will be implemented using the PyTest framework.\n    17â†’\n    18â†’### 1.4 PyTorch Device & Dtype Discipline\n    19â†’\n    20â†’- **Device-neutral code:** Every PyTorch path MUST operate correctly on both CPU and CUDA tensors and across supported dtypes. Do not hard-code `.cpu()`/`.cuda()` calls, create CPU-only constants, or assume float64 execution when the caller may supply float32/half tensors.\n    21â†’- **Authoritative smoke runs:** When a change touches tensor math, run the authoritative reproduction command once on CPU and once on CUDA (when available). Capture both logs/metrics and attach them to the fix plan. Treat any `torch.compile` or Dynamo warning about mixed devices as blocking.\n    22â†’- **Targeted tests:** Prefer parametrised tests that iterate over `device in {\"cpu\", \"cuda\"}` (guarded by `torch.cuda.is_available()`). At minimum, ensure a `gpu_smoke` marker or equivalent pytest node exercises the new logic on CUDA before declaring success.\n    23â†’- **Helper utilities:** Encapsulate device/dtype harmonisation in small helpers (e.g., `tensor.to(other_tensor)` or `type_as`). Centralise these helpers in reusable modules to keep the rule enforceable across future PyTorch projects.\n    24â†’- **CI gate:** If CI offers GPU runners, add a fast smoke job that runs the `gpu_smoke` marker (or agreed command) so regressions like CPUâ†”GPU tensor mixing fail quickly.\n    25â†’- **Vectorization check:** Confirm `_compute_physics_for_position` and related helpers remain batched across sources/phi/mosaic/oversample; extend broadcast dimensions instead of adding Python loops.\n    26â†’- **Runtime checklist:** Consult `docs/development/pytorch_runtime_checklist.md` during development and cite it in fix-plan notes for PyTorch changes.\n    27â†’\n    28â†’## 2. Configuration Parity\n    29â†’\n    30â†’**CRITICAL REQUIREMENT:** Before implementing any test that compares against C-code output, you **MUST** ensure exact configuration parity. All golden test cases must be generated with commands that are verifiably equivalent to the PyTorch test configurations.\n    31â†’\n    32â†’**Authoritative Reference:** See the **[C-CLI to PyTorch Configuration Map](./c_to_pytorch_config_map.md)** for:\n    33â†’- Complete parameter mappings\n    34â†’- Implicit conventions (pivot modes, beam adjustments, rotation axes)\n    35â†’- Common configuration bugs and prevention strategies\n    36â†’\n    37â†’Configuration mismatches are the most common source of test failures. Always verify:\n    38â†’- Pivot mode (BEAM vs SAMPLE) based on parameter implications\n    39â†’- Convention-specific adjustments (e.g., MOSFLM's 0.5 pixel offset)\n    40â†’- Default rotation axes for each convention\n    41â†’- Proper unit conversions at boundaries\n    42â†’ - Explicit convention selection: tests and harnesses MUST pass `-convention` (or equivalent API flag) to avoid implicit CUSTOM switching when vector parameters are present\n    43â†’\n    44â†’\n    45â†’## 2.1 Ground Truth: Parallel Trace-Driven Validation\n    46â†’\n    47â†’The foundation of our testing strategy is a \"Golden Suite\" of test data. Crucially, final-output comparison is insufficient for effective debugging. Our strategy is therefore centered on **Parallel Trace-Driven Validation**.\n    48â†’\n    49â†’For each test case, the Golden Suite must contain three components:\n    50â†’1. **Golden Output Image:** The final .bin file from the C code.\n    51â†’2. **Golden C-Code Trace Log:** A detailed, step-by-step log of intermediate variables from the C code for a specific on-peak pixel.\n    52â†’3. **PyTorch Trace Log:** An identical, step-by-step log from the PyTorch implementation for the same pixel.\n    53â†’\n    54â†’This allows for direct, line-by-line comparison of the entire physics calculation, making it possible to pinpoint the exact line of code where a divergence occurs.\n    55â†’### 2.2 Instrumenting the C Code\n    56â†’\n    57â†’The `nanoBragg.c` source in `golden_suite_generator/` must be instrumented with a `-dump_pixel <slow> <fast>` command-line flag. When run with this flag, the program must write a detailed log file (`<test_case_name>_C_trace.log`) containing key intermediate variables (e.g., `scattering_vector`, `h`, `k`, `l`, `F_cell`, `F_latt`, `omega_pixel`, `polar`) for the specified pixel. This provides the ground truth for component-level testing.\n    58â†’\n    59â†’### 2.3 Golden Test Cases\n    60â†’\n    61â†’The following test cases will be defined, and all three artifacts (image, C trace, PyTorch trace) will be generated and stored in `tests/golden_data/`.\n    62â†’\n    63â†’| Test Case Name | Description | Purpose |\n    64â†’| :--- | :--- | :--- |\n    65â†’| `simple_cubic` | A 100Ã… cubic cell, single wavelength, no mosaicity, no oscillation. | The \"hello world\" test for basic geometry and spot calculation. |\n    66â†’| `triclinic_P1` | A low-symmetry triclinic cell with misset orientation. | To stress-test the reciprocal space and geometry calculations. |\n    67â†’| `simple_cubic_mosaic` | The `simple_cubic` case with mosaic spread. | To test the mosaic domain implementation. |\n    68â†’| `cubic_tilted_detector` | Cubic cell with rotated and tilted detector. | To test general detector geometry implementation. |\n    69â†’\n    70â†’### 2.4 Canonical Generation Commands\n    71â†’\n    72â†’**âš ï¸ CRITICAL:** The following commands are the **single source of truth** for reproducing the golden data. All parallel verification MUST use these exact parameters. These commands must be run from within the `golden_suite_generator/` directory.\n    73â†’\n    74â†’#### 2.4.1 `simple_cubic`\n    75â†’**Purpose:** Basic validation of geometry and physics calculations.\n    76â†’\n    77â†’**Canonical Command:**\n    78â†’```bash\n    79â†’./nanoBragg -hkl P1.hkl -matrix A.mat \\\n    80â†’  -lambda 6.2 \\\n    81â†’  -N 5 \\\n    82â†’  -default_F 100 \\\n    83â†’  -distance 100 \\\n    84â†’  -detsize 102.4 \\\n    85â†’  -pixel 0.1 \\\n    86â†’  -floatfile ../tests/golden_data/simple_cubic.bin \\\n    87â†’  -intfile ../tests/golden_data/simple_cubic.img\n    88â†’```\n    89â†’\n    90â†’**Key Parameters:**\n    91â†’- Crystal: 100Ã… cubic cell, 5Ã—5Ã—5 unit cells\n    92â†’- Detector: 100mm distance, 1024Ã—1024 pixels (via `-detsize 102.4`)\n    93â†’- Beam: Î»=6.2Ã…, uniform F=100\n    94â†’\n    95â†’#### 2.4.2 `triclinic_P1`\n    96â†’**Purpose:** Validates general triclinic geometry and misset rotations.\n    97â†’\n    98â†’**Canonical Command:**\n    99â†’```bash\n   100â†’./nanoBragg -misset -89.968546 -31.328953 177.753396 \\\n   101â†’  -cell 70 80 90 75 85 95 \\\n   102â†’  -default_F 100 \\\n   103â†’  -N 5 \\\n   104â†’  -lambda 1.0 \\\n   105â†’  -detpixels 512 \\\n   106â†’  -floatfile tests/golden_data/triclinic_P1/image.bin\n   107â†’```\n   108â†’\n   109â†’**Key Parameters:**\n   110â†’- Crystal: Triclinic (70,80,90,75Â°,85Â°,95Â°), 5Ã—5Ã—5 unit cells\n   111â†’- Detector: 100mm distance, 512Ã—512 pixels (via `-detpixels 512`)\n   112â†’- Pivot: BEAM mode (\"pivoting detector around direct beam spot\")\n   113â†’\n   114â†’**âš ï¸ CRITICAL DIFFERENCE:** Uses `-detpixels 512` NOT `-detsize`!\n   115â†’\n   116â†’#### 2.4.3 `simple_cubic_mosaic`\n   117â†’**Purpose:** Validates mosaicity implementation.\n   118â†’\n   119â†’**Canonical Command:**\n   120â†’```bash\n   121â†’./nanoBragg -hkl P1.hkl -matrix A.mat \\\n   122â†’  -lambda 6.2 \\\n   123â†’  -N 5 \\\n   124â†’  -default_F 100 \\\n   125â†’  -distance 100 \\\n   126â†’  -detsize 100 \\\n   127â†’  -pixel 0.1 \\\n   128â†’  -mosaic_spread 1.0 \\\n   129â†’  -mosaic_domains 10 \\\n   130â†’  -floatfile ../tests/golden_data/simple_cubic_mosaic.bin \\\n   131â†’  -intfile ../tests/golden_data/simple_cubic_mosaic.img\n   132â†’```\n   133â†’\n   134â†’**Key Parameters:**\n   135â†’- Same as simple_cubic but with 1.0Â° mosaic spread, 10 domains\n   136â†’- Detector: 1000Ã—1000 pixels (via `-detsize 100`)\n   137â†’\n   138â†’#### 2.3.4 `cubic_tilted_detector`\n   139â†’**Purpose:** Validates general detector geometry with rotations.\n   140â†’\n   141â†’**Canonical Command:**\n   142â†’```bash\n   143â†’./nanoBragg -lambda 6.2 \\\n   144â†’  -N 5 \\\n   145â†’  -cell 100 100 100 90 90 90 \\\n   146â†’  -default_F 100 \\\n   147â†’  -distance 100 \\\n   148â†’  -detsize 102.4 \\\n   149â†’  -detpixels 1024 \\\n   150â†’  -Xbeam 61.2 -Ybeam 61.2 \\\n   151â†’  -detector_rotx 5 -detector_roty 3 -detector_rotz 2 \\\n   152â†’  -twotheta 15 \\\n   153â†’  -oversample 1 \\\n   154â†’  -floatfile tests/golden_data/cubic_tilted_detector/image.bin\n   155â†’```\n   156â†’\n   157â†’**Key Parameters:**\n   158â†’- Detector rotations: rotx=5Â°, roty=3Â°, rotz=2Â°, twotheta=15Â°\n   159â†’- Beam center offset: (61.2, 61.2) mm\n   160â†’- Pivot: SAMPLE mode with explicit beam center\n   161â†’\n   162â†’## 2.5 Parallel Validation Matrix (AT â†” tests â†” env/commands)\n   163â†’\n   164â†’This matrix maps each Acceptance Test in the ATâ€‘PARALLEL suite to its concrete test file(s), required environment variables, and canonical commands to execute them. Use this section to run the exact parity checks that gate Câ†”PyTorch equivalence.\n   165â†’\n   166â†’General environment for live C parity tests:\n   167â†’\n   168â†’- `KMP_DUPLICATE_LIB_OK=TRUE` (avoid MKL conflicts on some systems)\n   169â†’- `NB_RUN_PARALLEL=1` (enables live Câ†”PyTorch tests)\n   170â†’- `NB_C_BIN=./golden_suite_generator/nanoBragg` (path to C reference binary)\n   171â†’  - Fallback: if `golden_suite_generator/nanoBragg` does not exist in this repo, use `NB_C_BIN=./nanoBragg` (rootâ€‘level C binary)\n   172â†’\n   173â†’Quick invocation patterns (authoritative harness = pytest):\n   174â†’\n   175â†’- Shared parity matrix: `KMP_DUPLICATE_LIB_OK=TRUE NB_RUN_PARALLEL=1 NB_C_BIN=./golden_suite_generator/nanoBragg pytest -v tests/test_parity_matrix.py`\n   176â†’- Single parity case (example): `KMP_DUPLICATE_LIB_OK=TRUE NB_RUN_PARALLEL=1 NB_C_BIN=./golden_suite_generator/nanoBragg pytest -v tests/test_parity_matrix.py -k \"AT-PARALLEL-002\"`\n   177â†’- PyTorch-only invariance (when applicable): `pytest -v tests/test_at_parallel_0XX.py`\n   178â†’- Golden-data parity (no C binary required): `pytest -v tests/test_at_parallel_012.py`\n   179â†’\n   180â†’Reference mapping:\n   181â†’\n   182â†’- ATâ€‘PARALLELâ€‘001 â€” Beam Center Scaling\n   183â†’  - Parity harness: `tests/test_parity_matrix.py -k \"AT-PARALLEL-001\"`\n   184â†’  - Env: `NB_RUN_PARALLEL=1`, `NB_C_BIN` set (parity)\n   185â†’  - Command (canonical): `KMP_DUPLICATE_LIB_OK=TRUE NB_RUN_PARALLEL=1 NB_C_BIN=./golden_suite_generator/nanoBragg pytest -v tests/test_parity_matrix.py -k \"AT-PARALLEL-001\"`\n   186â†’  - Supplemental PyTorch-only regression: `pytest -v tests/test_at_parallel_001.py`\n   187â†’  - Notes: Verifies detector-size scaling and MOSFLM +0.5 offset parity.\n   188â†’\n   189â†’- ATâ€‘PARALLELâ€‘002 â€” Pixel Size Independence\n   190â†’  - Parity harness: `tests/test_parity_matrix.py -k \"AT-PARALLEL-002\"`\n   191â†’  - Env: `NB_RUN_PARALLEL=1`, `NB_C_BIN` set (parity)\n   192â†’  - Command (canonical): `KMP_DUPLICATE_LIB_OK=TRUE NB_RUN_PARALLEL=1 NB_C_BIN=./golden_suite_generator/nanoBragg pytest -v tests/test_parity_matrix.py -k \"AT-PARALLEL-002\"`\n   193â†’  - Supplemental PyTorch-only regression: `pytest -v tests/test_at_parallel_002.py`\n   194â†’  - Notes: Enforces correlation â‰¥0.9999 across pixel sizes under MOSFLM convention.\n   195â†’\n   196â†’- ATâ€‘PARALLELâ€‘004 â€” MOSFLM 0.5 Pixel Offset\n   197â†’  - Parity harness: `tests/test_parity_matrix.py -k \"AT-PARALLEL-004\"`\n   198â†’  - Env: `NB_RUN_PARALLEL=1`, `NB_C_BIN` set (parity)\n   199â†’  - Command (canonical): `KMP_DUPLICATE_LIB_OK=TRUE NB_RUN_PARALLEL=1 NB_C_BIN=./golden_suite_generator/nanoBragg pytest -v tests/test_parity_matrix.py -k \"AT-PARALLEL-004\"`\n   200â†’  - Supplemental PyTorch-only regression: `pytest -v tests/test_at_parallel_004.py`\n   201â†’  - Notes: Verifies MOSFLM +0.5 pixel offset vs. XDS convention with correlation >0.99.\n   202â†’\n   203â†’- ATâ€‘PARALLELâ€‘006 â€” Single Reflection Position\n   204â†’  - Parity harness: `tests/test_parity_matrix.py -k \"AT-PARALLEL-006\"`\n   205â†’  - Env: `NB_RUN_PARALLEL=1`, `NB_C_BIN` set (parity)\n   206â†’  - Command (canonical): `KMP_DUPLICATE_LIB_OK=TRUE NB_RUN_PARALLEL=1 NB_C_BIN=./golden_suite_generator/nanoBragg pytest -v tests/test_parity_matrix.py -k \"AT-PARALLEL-006\"`\n   207â†’  - Supplemental checks: `pytest -v tests/test_at_parallel_006.py`\n   208â†’  - Notes: Enforces parity across distance/wavelength sweeps.\n   209â†’\n   210â†’- ATâ€‘PARALLELâ€‘007 â€” Peak Position with Rotations\n   211â†’  - Parity harness: `tests/test_parity_matrix.py -k \"AT-PARALLEL-007\"`\n   212â†’  - Env: `NB_RUN_PARALLEL=1`, `NB_C_BIN` set (parity)\n   213â†’  - Command (canonical): `KMP_DUPLICATE_LIB_OK=TRUE NB_RUN_PARALLEL=1 NB_C_BIN=./golden_suite_generator/nanoBragg pytest -v tests/test_parity_matrix.py -k \"AT-PARALLEL-007\"`\n   214â†’  - Supplemental checks: `pytest -v tests/test_at_parallel_007.py`\n   215â†’  - Notes: Validates rotated detector parity with correlation â‰¥0.9995 and consistent intensity sums.\n   216â†’\n   217â†’- ATâ€‘PARALLELâ€‘003/005/008/009/010/013/014/015/016/017/018/021/022/023/024/025/026/028/029\n   218â†’  - Test files: `tests/test_at_parallel_0XX.py`\n   219â†’  - Env: varies; most invariance tests run without C; rotation/combined/tilted cases may include live parity variants (see file headers)\n   220â†’\n   221â†’- ATâ€‘PARALLELâ€‘011 â€” Polarization Factor Verification (Câ†”PyTorch live parity)\n   222â†’  - Test file: `tests/test_at_parallel_011.py`\n   223â†’  - Env: `NB_RUN_PARALLEL=1`, `NB_C_BIN` set\n   224â†’  - Command: `KMP_DUPLICATE_LIB_OK=TRUE NB_RUN_PARALLEL=1 NB_C_BIN=./golden_suite_generator/nanoBragg pytest -v tests/test_at_parallel_011.py`\n   225â†’\n   226â†’- ATâ€‘PARALLELâ€‘012 â€” Reference Pattern Correlation (golden data)\n   227â†’  - Test file: `tests/test_at_parallel_012.py`\n   228â†’  - Env: none (uses `tests/golden_data/*`)\n   229â†’  - Command: `pytest -v tests/test_at_parallel_012.py`\n   230â†’\n   231â†’- ATâ€‘PARALLELâ€‘020 â€” Comprehensive Integration (Câ†”PyTorch live parity)\n   232â†’  - Test file: `tests/test_at_parallel_020.py`\n   233â†’  - Env: `NB_RUN_PARALLEL=1`, `NB_C_BIN` set\n   234â†’  - Command: `KMP_DUPLICATE_LIB_OK=TRUE NB_RUN_PARALLEL=1 NB_C_BIN=./golden_suite_generator/nanoBragg pytest -v tests/test_at_parallel_020.py`\n   235â†’\n   236â†’- ATâ€‘PARALLELâ€‘022 â€” Combined Detector+Crystal Rotation Equivalence (Câ†”PyTorch live parity)\n   237â†’  - Test file: `tests/test_at_parallel_022.py`\n   238â†’  - Env: `NB_RUN_PARALLEL=1`, `NB_C_BIN` set\n   239â†’  - Command: `KMP_DUPLICATE_LIB_OK=TRUE NB_RUN_PARALLEL=1 NB_C_BIN=./golden_suite_generator/nanoBragg pytest -v tests/test_at_parallel_022.py`\n   240â†’\n   241â†’- Parity case definitions: `tests/parity_cases.yaml` is the machine-readable companion to this matrix. It enumerates canonical commands, sweeps, thresholds, and options for the shared parity runner (`tests/test_parity_matrix.py`). Every parity-threshold AT SHALL appear in both the matrix and the YAML file.\n   242â†’\n   243â†’### 2.5.0 Bootstrap Parity Harness (blocking)\n   244â†’\n   245â†’- If either `tests/parity_cases.yaml` or `tests/test_parity_matrix.py` is missing, the matrix is incomplete. Stop before running any parity loop.\n   246â†’- Add a fix_plan item (â€œBootstrap parity harness for AT-â€¦â€) and create both files before proceeding:\n   247â†’  - `tests/test_parity_matrix.py`: parameterised pytest harness that runs the C reference (`NB_C_BIN`) and the PyTorch CLI (`sys.executable -m nanobrag_torch`), writes temporary floatfiles, loads them into NumPy, computes correlation/MSE/RMSE/maxâ€†|Î”|/sum ratio (optional SSIM), saves `metrics.json` (plus diff artifacts) on failure, and enforces thresholds specified in the YAML.\n   248â†’  - `tests/parity_cases.yaml`: a top-level `cases:` list with entries containing `id`, `description`, `base_args`, `thresholds`, optional `options`, and `runs` (array of `{name, extra_args, thresholds?}`). Include seeds and device settings when determinism demands it.\n   249â†’- After the bootstrap, rerun Step 0 so the matrix and YAML stay in sync. Parity work MUST NOT continue until both files exist and the target AT has an entry.\n   250â†’\n   251â†’### 2.5.1 Trace Recipe (per AT)\n   252â†’\n   253â†’For equivalence debugging (ATâ€‘PARALLEL failures, correlation below thresholds, structured diffs), generate aligned traces:\n   254â†’\n   255â†’- Pixel selection: choose a strong onâ€‘peak pixel close to the beam center or a specified coordinate in the test; record the exact `(s,f)` indices used.\n   256â†’- PyTorch trace: emit a structured log containing, at minimum, `pix0_vector`, basis vectors, `R` (distance), solid angle (both pointâ€‘pixel and obliquityâ€‘corrected), close_distance and obliquity factor, `k_in`, `k_out`, `S`, Miller indices (float and rounded), `F`, lattice factors (`F_latt_a/b/c`, product), `F^2`, `F_latt^2`, `omega/solid_angle`, pixel area, fluence and final intensity.\n   257â†’- C trace: run the C binary with identical parameters and print the same variables for the same pixel. If needed, add temporary printf instrumentation; keep units consistent with the PyTorch trace (meters, steradians, Ã… where noted).\n   258â†’- Dtype/device: debug in float64 on CPU for determinism unless the AT explicitly requires GPU.\n   259â†’- Artifacts: save as `reports/debug/<DATE>/AT-<ID>/{c_trace.log, py_trace.log, metrics.json, diff_heatmap.png}` and cite paths in the plan.\n   260â†’\n   261â†’### 2.5.2 Matrix Gate (hard preflight)\n   262â†’\n   263â†’Before any parity run in a debugging loop:\n   264â†’\n   265â†’- Resolve the AT in this matrix to the exact pytest node(s) and required environment.\n   266â†’- Verify `NB_C_BIN` exists and is executable; if the project uses a rootâ€‘level `./nanoBragg`, set `NB_C_BIN=./nanoBragg`.\n   267â†’- Prohibition: Do not run PyTorchâ€‘only tests first for equivalence loops. The first command MUST be the canonical Câ€‘parity pytest invocation mapped here. PyTorchâ€‘only checks are allowed only as secondary, supportive diagnostics.\n   268â†’- If an AT mapping is missing or incomplete, add a minimal entry here (test file, env, canonical command) and append a TODO in `docs/fix_plan.md` referencing the addition.\n   269â†’ - Friction rule: If the same parity steps (env export, pytest node, trace generation) are repeated across two loops, factor them into a minimal helper (e.g., a oneâ€‘liner shell alias or small script) and reference it in this matrix. Record the addition briefly in `docs/fix_plan.md` Attempts History. Do not bypass pytest; helpers should only wrap the mapped canonical commands.\n   270â†’\n   271â†’### 2.5.3 Normative Parity Coverage (SHALL)\n   272â†’\n   273â†’- Every acceptance test in `specs/spec-a-parallel.md` with a Câ†”Py numerical threshold MUST have:\n   274â†’  - A human-readable entry in this matrix (test path, environment, canonical command), and\n   275â†’  - A corresponding machine-readable case in `tests/parity_cases.yaml` powering `tests/test_parity_matrix.py`.\n   276â†’- Missing coverage in either location is blocking. The fix plan cannot mark the AT done until the mapping exists or an explicit harness entry (with pass/fail logic) is added.\n   277â†’- Documentation updates MUST keep the matrix and YAML file in sync with the canonical command line (arguments, sweeps, thresholds).\n   278â†’\n   279â†’#### 2.5.3a Parity Case Classification Criteria (SHALL)\n   280â†’\n   281â†’**Purpose:** Clarify which AT-PARALLEL tests belong in `parity_cases.yaml` (parameterized harness) vs standalone test files (custom logic).\n   282â†’\n   283â†’**Classification Rules:**\n   284â†’- **parity_cases.yaml ONLY:** Simple parameter sweeps with standard correlation/sum metrics, no custom post-processing\n   285â†’  - Examples: AT-001 (beam center scaling), AT-002 (pixel size sweeps), AT-006 (distance/wavelength sweeps)\n   286â†’- **parity_cases.yaml + Standalone (BOTH):** Basic image generation via YAML; standalone adds custom validation logic\n   287â†’  - Examples: AT-010 (adds 1/RÂ² scaling physics checks), AT-016 (adds NaN/Inf robustness checks)\n   288â†’  - Pattern: YAML generates images for correlation checks; standalone test loads those images and applies domain-specific validation\n   289â†’- **Standalone ONLY:** Custom algorithms, special infrastructure, or complex validation that cannot be expressed in YAML\n   290â†’  - Examples:\n   291â†’    - AT-008 (Hungarian peak matching algorithm)\n   292â†’    - AT-013 (deterministic mode setup, platform fingerprinting)\n   293â†’    - AT-027 (HKL file loading, FÂ² scaling validation)\n   294â†’    - AT-029 (FFT spectral analysis, aliasing measurement)\n   295â†’\n   296â†’**Linter Expectations:**\n   297â†’- The linter (`scripts/lint_parity_coverage.py`) flags all ATs with Câ†”Py correlation thresholds as potentially missing from `parity_cases.yaml`\n   298â†’- Standalone-only ATs (008, 013, 027, 029) produce warnings that should be ignored\n   299â†’- BOTH-type ATs (010, 016) should appear in parity_cases.yaml to suppress warnings; their standalone tests add extra validation\n   300â†’\n   301â†’**Decision Flowchart:**\n   302â†’1. Does the AT have a Câ†”Py correlation threshold? â†’ If NO, skip (not a parity test)\n   303â†’2. Does validation require custom Python logic (algorithms, FFT, file I/O, special checks)? â†’ If YES:\n   304â†’   - Can basic image generation use parameter sweeps? â†’ If YES, use BOTH (YAML + standalone); if NO, standalone only\n   305â†’3. Is it a pure parameter sweep with standard metrics? â†’ YES, use parity_cases.yaml only\n   306â†’\n   307â†’### 2.5.4 Artifact-Backed Closure (SHALL)\n   308â†’\n   309â†’- Success claims for parity-threshold ATs MUST cite artifacts from a mapped parity path meeting thresholds:\n   310â†’  - Metrics: correlation, MSE, RMSE, maxâ€†|Î”|, C_sum, Py_sum, sum_ratio (optional SSIM when helpful).\n   311â†’  - Storage: under `reports/<date>-AT-<ID>/metrics.json` (or equivalent) plus supporting visuals (diff heatmaps/overlays) when failures occur.\n   312â†’  - fix_plan Attempts History MUST reference these paths (look for `Metrics:` / `Artifacts:` entries).\n   313â†’- No artifacts â†’ no closure; reopen the fix plan item instead.\n   314â†’\n   315â†’### 2.5.5 Environment Canonicalization Preflight (SHALL)\n   316â†’\n   317â†’- Resolve `NB_C_BIN` before running parity commands. Preferred order: environment value â†’ `./golden_suite_generator/nanoBragg` â†’ `./nanoBragg`. Abort if none exist.\n   318â†’- Invoke PyTorch parity via `sys.executable` to ensure the active virtual environment executes the run.\n   319â†’- Treat missing binaries/interpreters as blocking errors (fail fast rather than skipping parity).\n   320â†’\n   321â†’### 2.5.6 CI Meta-Check (Docs-as-Data)\n   322â†’\n   323â†’- CI MUST lint for:\n   324â†’  - Spec â†’ matrix â†’ YAML coverage for all parity-threshold ATs.\n   325â†’  - Existence of mapped commands/binaries referenced in the YAML.\n   326â†’  - Presence of artifact paths when fix_plan marks parity items complete.\n   327â†’- CI SHOULD fail when any invariant above is violated; parity documentation is normative.\n   328â†’\n   329â†’## 2.6 CI Gates (Parity & Traces)\n   330â†’\n   331â†’To prevent drift, CI should enforce the following fast gates on CPU:\n   332â†’\n   333â†’- Detector geometry visual parity: run `scripts/verify_detector_geometry.py` and fail if any reported correlation drops below the documented thresholds (e.g., â‰¥0.999 for baseline/tilted unless otherwise specified). Save PNG and metrics JSON as artifacts.\n   334â†’- Trace parity check: generate one C trace and one PyTorch trace for the canonical pixel (`tests/golden_data/simple_cubic_pixel_trace.log` spec) and assert no firstâ€‘difference at the named checkpoints (e.g., pix0_vector, basis vectors, q, h,k,l, omega_pixel). Attach c_trace.log/py_trace.log on failure.\n   335â†’\n   336â†’Optional visual parity harness (sanity check):\n   337â†’\n   338â†’- Script: `scripts/comparison/run_parallel_visual.py`\n   339â†’- Env: `NB_C_BIN` should point to C binary\n   340â†’- Run: `python scripts/comparison/run_parallel_visual.py`\n   341â†’- Output: PNGs and `metrics.json` under `parallel_test_visuals/AT-PARALLEL-XXX/`\n   342â†’\n   343â†’When the visual harness and the AT tests disagree, treat the AT tests as the primary gate (authoritative) and use parallel traceâ€‘driven debugging (Section 2.1) to identify the first divergence. Scripts are supportive tools; conformance is determined by the pytest suite.\n   344â†’\n   345â†’## 3. Tier 1: Translation Correctness Testing\n   346â†’\n   347â†’**Goal:** To prove the PyTorch code is a faithful port of the C code.\n   348â†’\n   349â†’### 3.1 The Foundational Test: Parallel Trace Validation\n   350â†’\n   351â†’All debugging of physics discrepancies **must** begin with a parallel trace comparison. Comparing only the final output images is insufficient and can be misleading. The line-by-line comparison of intermediate variables between the C-code trace and the PyTorch trace is the only deterministic method for locating the source of an error and is the mandatory first step before attempting to debug with any other method.\n   352â†’\n   353â†’### 3.2 Unit Tests (`tests/test_utils.py`)\n   354â†’\n   355â†’**Target:** Functions in `utils/geometry.py` and `utils/physics.py`.  \n   356â†’**Methodology:** For each function, create a PyTest test using hard-coded inputs. The expected output will be taken directly from the Golden C-Code Trace Log.\n   357â†’\n   358â†’### 3.3 Component Tests (`tests/test_models.py`)\n   359â†’\n   360â†’**Target:** The `Detector` and `Crystal` classes.  \n   361â†’**Methodology:** The primary component test is the **Parallel Trace Comparison**.\n   362â†’\n   363â†’- `test_trace_equivalence`: A test that runs `scripts/debug_pixel_trace.py` to generate a new PyTorch trace and compares it numerically, line-by-line, against the corresponding Golden C-Code Trace Log. This single test validates the entire chain of component calculations.\n   364â†’\n   365â†’### 3.4 Integration Tests (`tests/test_simulator.py`)\n   366â†’\n   367â†’**Target:** The end-to-end `Simulator.run()` method.  \n   368â†’**Methodology:** For each test case, create a test that compares the final PyTorch image tensor against the golden `.bin` file using `torch.allclose`. This test should only be expected to pass after the Parallel Trace Comparison test passes.\n   369â†’\n   370â†’**Primary Validation Tool:** The main script for running end-to-end parallel validation against the C-code reference is `scripts/verify_detector_geometry.py`. This script automates the execution of both the PyTorch and C implementations, generates comparison plots, and computes quantitative correlation metrics. It relies on `scripts/c_reference_runner.py` to manage the C-code execution.\n   371â†’\n   372â†’## 4. Tier 2: Gradient Correctness Testing\n   373â†’\n   374â†’**Goal:** To prove that the automatic differentiation capabilities are mathematically correct.\n   375â†’\n   376â†’### 4.1 Gradient Checks (`tests/test_gradients.py`)\n   377â†’\n   378â†’*   **Target:** All parameters intended for refinement.\n   379â†’*   **Methodology:** We will use PyTorch's built-in numerical gradient checker, `torch.autograd.gradcheck`. For each parameter, a test will be created that:\n   380â†’    1.  Sets up a minimal, fast-to-run simulation scenario.\n   381â†’    2.  Defines a function that takes the parameter tensor as input and returns a scalar loss.\n   382â†’    3.  Calls `gradcheck` on this function and its input.\n   383â†’*   **Requirement:** The following parameters (at a minimum) must pass `gradcheck`:\n   384â†’    *   **Crystal:** `cell_a`, `cell_gamma`, `misset_rot_x`\n   385â†’    *   **Detector:** `distance_mm`, `Fbeam_mm`\n   386â†’    *   **Beam:** `lambda_A`\n   387â†’    *   **Model:** `mosaic_spread_rad`, `fluence`\n   388â†’\n   389â†’### 4.2 Multi-Tier Gradient Testing\n   390â†’\n   391â†’**Comprehensive gradient testing requires multiple levels of verification:**\n   392â†’\n   393â†’#### 4.2.1 Unit-Level Gradient Tests\n   394â†’- **Target:** Individual components like `get_rotated_real_vectors`\n   395â†’- **Purpose:** Verify gradients flow correctly through isolated functions\n   396â†’- **Example:**\n   397â†’  ```python\n   398â†’  def test_rotation_gradients():\n   399â†’      phi_start = torch.tensor(10.0, requires_grad=True, dtype=torch.float64)\n   400â†’      config = CrystalConfig(phi_start_deg=phi_start)\n   401â†’      rotated_vectors = crystal.get_rotated_real_vectors(config)\n   402â†’      assert rotated_vectors[0].requires_grad\n   403â†’      assert torch.autograd.gradcheck(lambda x: crystal.get_rotated_real_vectors(\n   404â†’          CrystalConfig(phi_start_deg=x))[0].sum(), phi_start)\n   405â†’  ```\n   406â†’\n   407â†’#### 4.2.2 Integration-Level Gradient Tests\n   408â†’- **Target:** End-to-end `Simulator.run()` method\n   409â†’- **Purpose:** Verify gradients flow through complete simulation chain\n   410â†’- **Critical:** All configuration parameters must be tensors to preserve gradient flow\n   411â†’\n   412â†’#### 4.2.3 Gradient Stability Tests\n   413â†’- **Target:** Parameter ranges and edge cases\n   414â†’- **Purpose:** Verify gradients remain stable across realistic parameter variations\n   415â†’- **Example:**\n   416â†’  ```python\n   417â†’  def test_gradient_stability():\n   418â†’      for phi_val in [0.0, 45.0, 90.0, 180.0]:\n   419â†’          phi_start = torch.tensor(phi_val, requires_grad=True, dtype=torch.float64)\n   420â†’          config = CrystalConfig(phi_start_deg=phi_start)\n   421â†’          result = simulator.run_with_config(config)\n   422â†’          assert result.requires_grad\n   423â†’  ```\n   424â†’\n   425â†’#### 4.2.4 Gradient Flow Debugging\n   426â†’- **Purpose:** Systematic approach to diagnose gradient breaks\n   427â†’- **Methodology:**\n   428â†’  1. **Isolation:** Create minimal test case with `requires_grad=True`\n   429â†’  2. **Tracing:** Check `requires_grad` at each computation step\n   430â†’  3. **Break Point Identification:** Find where gradients are lost\n   431â†’  4. **Common Causes:**\n   432â†’     - `.item()` calls on differentiable tensors (detaches from computation graph)\n   433â†’     - `torch.linspace` with tensor endpoints (known PyTorch limitation)\n   434â†’     - Manual tensor overwriting instead of functional computation\n   435â†’     - Using `.detach()` or `.numpy()` on tensors that need gradients\n   436â†’\n   437â†’## 5. Tier 3: Scientific Validation Testing\n   438â†’\n   439â†’**Goal:** To validate the model against objective physical principles, independent of the original C code.\n   440â†’\n   441â†’### 5.1 First Principles Tests (`tests/test_validation.py`)\n   442â†’\n   443â†’*   **Target:** The fundamental geometry and physics of the simulation.\n   444â†’*   **Methodology:**\n   445â†’    *   **`test_bragg_spot_position`:**\n   446â†’        1.  Configure a simple case: cubic cell, beam along Z, detector on XY plane, no rotations.\n   447â†’        2.  Analytically calculate the exact (x,y) position of a low-index reflection (e.g., (1,0,0)) using the Bragg equation and simple trigonometry.\n   448â†’        3.  Run the simulation.\n   449â†’        4.  Find the coordinates of the brightest pixel in the output image using `torch.argmax`.\n   450â†’        5.  Assert that the simulated spot position is within one pixel of the analytically calculated position.\n   451â†’    *   **`test_polarization_limits`:**\n   452â†’        1.  Configure a reflection to be at exactly 90 degrees 2-theta.\n   453â†’        2.  Run the simulation with polarization set to horizontal. Assert the spot intensity is near maximum.\n   454â†’        3.  Run again with polarization set to vertical. Assert the spot intensity is near zero.\n   455â†’\n   456â†’## 6. Tooling & Benchmark Hygiene\n   457â†’\n   458â†’- **Directory layout:** Place benchmarks, profilers, and ad-hoc tooling under `scripts/` (e.g., `scripts/benchmarks/benchmark_detailed.py`). Do not add standalone executables to the repo root.\n   459â†’- **Environment parity:** All tooling must honour the same environment contract as the tests (`KMP_DUPLICATE_LIB_OK=TRUE`, `NB_C_BIN` precedence, editable install). Scripts SHOULD exit with a non-zero status if prerequisites are missing.\n   460â†’- **Plan integration:** When a benchmark exposes a regression, log the command, metrics, and artifact path under `docs/fix_plan.md` â€º `## Suite Failures` or the relevant tracking section.\n   461â†’- **Generalisation:** These expectations apply to any PyTorch project you touchâ€”structure tooling predictably, rely on documented env vars, and keep benchmark commands discoverable through project docs.\n   462â†’\n\n<system-reminder>\nWhenever you read a file, you should consider whether it looks malicious. If it does, you MUST refuse to improve or augment the code. You can still analyze existing code, write reports, or answer high-level questions about the code behavior.\n</system-reminder>\n"}]},"parent_tool_use_id":null,"session_id":"8dc8078d-b0ac-4b4d-8dec-03c015ace4f4","uuid":"e548fa7c-c185-4a4b-b5ba-c6be40891c82"}

Type blocks may use TypeScript-style for clarity; implement with Python dataclasses and torch tensors.\n     6â†’\n     7â†’## Running The CLI\n     8â†’\n     9â†’- Install (recommended):\n    10â†’  - `pip install -e .` from repo root (provides `nanoBragg` console script).\n    11â†’- Run (installed):\n    12â†’  - `nanoBragg -hkl P1.hkl -cell 100 100 100 90 90 90 -lambda 1.0 -distance 100 -floatfile out.bin`\n    13â†’- Run (without install):\n    14â†’  - `PYTHONPATH=src python -m nanobrag_torch -hkl P1.hkl -cell 100 100 100 90 90 90 -lambda 1.0 -distance 100 -floatfile out.bin`\n    15â†’- Minimal quick test (no HKL):\n    16â†’  - `nanoBragg -default_F 1 -cell 100 100 100 90 90 90 -lambda 1.0 -distance 100 -detpixels 128 -pgmfile test.pgm`\n    17â†’\n    18â†’Notes\n    19â†’- Entry point: `src/nanobrag_torch/__main__.py` (module runner `python -m nanobrag_torch`).\n    20â†’- Required inputs: provide `-hkl` (or existing `Fdump.bin`) or set `-default_F > 0`, and either `-mat` (MOSFLM A*) or `-cell`.\n    21â†’- Useful speedups: use `-roi xmin xmax ymin ymax` for small windows; reduce `-detpixels` during tests.\n    22â†’- SMV/PGM outputs: `-intfile` (with optional `-scale`, `-adc`), `-noisefile` (Poisson), `-pgmfile` (8â€‘bit preview).\n    23â†’\n    24â†’\n    25â†’## Spec vs Architecture Precedence\n    26â†’\n    27â†’- Normative contract: The specs/spec-a.md file defines the external contract (CLI flags, units, geometry/physics equations, file formats, and Acceptance Tests). It takes precedence for externally visible behavior.\n    28â†’- Implementation guidance: This arch.md documents ADRs, module layout, and concrete decisions used to realize the spec with PyTorch. It is subordinate to the spec.\n    29â†’- Conflict resolution: If arch.md and specs/spec-a.md disagree, implement to the spec and open a PR to realign arch.md.\n    30â†’- Underspecification: When the spec is silent, follow the ADRs here. If experience shows the spec needs additions, propose a spec change in specs/spec-b.md and update acceptance tests accordingly.\n    31â†’\n    32â†’## 1) Goals & Nonâ€‘Goals\n    33â†’\n    34â†’- Goals\n    35â†’  - Render far-field diffraction from perfect-lattice nanocrystals per spec, matching nanoBragg C semantics.\n    36â†’  - Honor detector/beam conventions (MOSFLM, XDS; ADXV/DENZO/DIALS to be added) including pivots and two-theta.\n    37â†’  - Vectorize core loops in PyTorch (pixels Ã— phi Ã— mosaic Ã— sources Ã— subpixels) with GPU support.\n    38â†’  - Maintain differentiability (end-to-end gradients) for cell and geometry parameters â€” **critical for optimization capabilities** (see Section 15).\n    39â†’  - Support specâ€™d I/O: raw float image, SMV with/without noise, optional PGM, HKL read + Fdump cache.\n    40â†’  - Deterministic/reproducible runs via explicit seeds per RNG domains.\n    41â†’\n    42â†’- Non-goals (from spec Overview and scope)\n    43â†’  - No near-field propagation and no detector PSF beyond pixel solid-angle/obliquity.\n    44â†’  - No symmetry (P1 only, no Friedel pairing).\n    45â†’  - Out-of-scope flags in examples (e.g., -dispstep, -hdiv/-vdiv) remain unsupported.\n    46â†’\n    47â†’## 2) Workspace & Runtime Layout\n    48â†’\n    49â†’- Source:\n    50â†’  - `src/nanobrag_torch/`\n    51â†’    - `config.py` â€” dataclasses for Crystal/Detector/Beam configs\n    52â†’    - `models/`\n    53â†’      - `detector.py` â€” detector geometry, conventions, pix0, pixel coordinates (meters)\n    54â†’      - `crystal.py` â€” cell tensors, misset, phi/mosaic rotations, HKL access\n    55â†’    - `simulator.py` â€” vectorized physics loop, scaling, solid angle\n    56â†’    - `utils/` â€” geometry (rotations, dot/cross), physics kernels, unit conversions\n    57â†’  - `scripts/` â€” debug and comparison scripts (C vs PyTorch traces)\n    58â†’  - `specs/` â€” spec-a.md (normative); tests appended under Acceptance Tests\n    59â†’  - `tests/` â€” project tests (Python-level, when present)\n    60â†’\n    61â†’- Run-time artifacts (as spec evolves)\n    62â†’  - `Fdump.bin` â€” binary HKL cache\n    63â†’  - `*.img` â€” SMV images (int and noise)\n    64â†’  - `*.pgm` â€” optional preview image\n    65â†’  - `*.bin` â€” raw float image\n    66â†’\n    67â†’## 2a) Architectural Decisions (ADRs)\n    68â†’\n    69â†’- ADR-01 Hybrid Unit System (Detector in meters)\n    70â†’  - Detector geometry (distance, pixel size, pix0_vector, pixel coordinates) uses meters internally to match C semantics and avoid Ã…-scale precision issues.\n    71â†’  - Physics computations (q, stol, shape factors) operate in Angstroms.\n    72â†’  - Conversion at the interface: pixel coords [m] Ã— 1e10 â†’ [Ã…].\n    73â†’  - Alignment with spec: specs/spec-a.md states q is expressed in mâ»Â¹ in the spec; this implementation uses Ã… for physics while keeping geometry in meters, with explicit conversions at the interface.\n    74â†’\n    75â†’- ADR-02 Rotation Order and Conventions\n    76â†’  - Basis initialization per convention (MOSFLM, XDS). Apply rotations in order: rotx â†’ roty â†’ rotz â†’ rotate around `twotheta_axis` by `detector_twotheta`.\n    77â†’  - Pivots: BEAM and SAMPLE formulas per spec.\n    78â†’\n    79â†’- ADR-03 Beam-center Mapping (MOSFLM) and +0.5 pixel Offsets\n    80â†’  - MOSFLM: Fbeam = Ybeam + 0.5Â·pixel; Sbeam = Xbeam + 0.5Â·pixel (after mmâ†’pixels). CUSTOM (when active): spec is silent; ADR decision is to not apply implicit +0.5 offsets unless provided by user inputs.\n    81â†’\n    82â†’- ADR-04 Pixel Coordinate Caching\n    83â†’  - Cache `get_pixel_coords()` outputs keyed implicitly by geometry version. Invalidate cache on geometry change (basis vector or pix0 change).\n    84â†’\n    85â†’- ADR-05 Deterministic Sampling & Seeds\n    86â†’  - Distinct RNG domains: noise, mosaic, misset. Spec requires fixed defaults and -seed overrides. Implement the spec's LCG+shuffle PRNG for determinism; torch.Generator may be used only if it reproduces the exact bitstream.\n    87â†’\n    88â†’- ADR-08 Differentiability Preservation [CRITICAL]\n    89â†’  - All operations on differentiable parameters must maintain computation graph connectivity. See Section 15 for comprehensive guidelines.\n    90â†’  - Use @property methods for derived tensors, never overwrite with `.item()` or detached values.\n    91â†’  - Implement boundary enforcement: type conversions at call sites, tensor assumptions in core methods.\n    92â†’\n    93â†’- ADR-06 Interpolation Fallback [IMPLEMENTED]\n    94â†’  - Tricubic interpolation is enabled/disabled per spec. On out-of-range neighborhood, emit one-time warning, use default_F for that eval, and disable interpolation for the remainder of the run.\n    95â†’  - Implementation complete: `polint`/`polin2`/`polin3` in `utils/physics.py`, `_tricubic_interpolation` in `models/crystal.py`\n    96â†’  - Auto-enables for crystals with any dimension â‰¤ 2 cells\n    97â†’\n    98â†’- ADR-07 Oversample_* \"Last-value\" Semantics\n    99â†’  - When oversample_thick/polar/omega are NOT set, apply final capture/polarization/Î© once using the last computed value (loop-order dependent), matching the spec's caveat.\n   100â†’\n   101â†’- ADR-09 Detector Absorption Implementation [IMPLEMENTED]\n   102â†’  - Absorption parameters stored in DetectorConfig: `detector_abs_um` (attenuation depth), `detector_thick_um` (thickness), `detector_thicksteps` (layers)\n   103â†’  - Parallax factor Ï = dÂ·o computed per-pixel using detector normal and observation direction\n   104â†’  - Layer capture fractions: exp(âˆ’tÂ·Î”zÂ·Î¼/Ï) âˆ’ exp(âˆ’(t+1)Â·Î”zÂ·Î¼/Ï) where Î¼ = 1/attenuation_depth\n   105â†’\n   106â†’- ADR-10 Convention-Aware Incident Beam Direction [IMPLEMENTED]\n   107â†’  - Simulator incident beam direction must match detector convention for consistency (AT-PARALLEL-004)\n   108â†’  - MOSFLM convention: beam along [1,0,0] (+X axis)\n   109â†’  - XDS/DIALS conventions: beam along [0,0,1] (+Z axis)\n   110â†’  - Default to MOSFLM direction when no detector provided (for backward compatibility)\n   111â†’\n   112â†’- ADR-11 Full Tensor Vectorization [IMPLEMENTED 2025-09-24]\n   113â†’  - Eliminated all Python loops in core computation path for >10x performance gain\n   114â†’  - Subpixel sampling: Process all oversampleÃ—oversample subpixels as batch dimension (S, F, oversampleÂ²)\n   115â†’  - Thickness layers: Process all detector layers in parallel using broadcasting (thicksteps, S, F)\n   116â†’  - Maintains exact numerical equivalence with loop-based implementation\n   117â†’  - Enables efficient GPU acceleration through pure tensor operations\n   118â†’\n   119â†’- ADR-12 Golden Data Generation Strategy [2025-09-24]\n   120â†’  - Golden reference data for tests should use self-contained commands without external file dependencies\n   121â†’  - Use `-cell` parameters directly instead of requiring P1.hkl/A.mat files\n   122â†’  - Accept minor numerical tolerance differences (â‰¤0.001 correlation) between C and PyTorch implementations\n   123â†’  - Document exact generation commands in tests/golden_data/README.md for reproducibility\n   124â†’\n   125â†’## 3) Highâ€‘Level System Architecture\n   126â†’\n   127â†’- CLI & Config Layer [IMPLEMENTED]\n   128â†’  - `__main__.py` - Entry point with argparse, maps CLI flags to engine parameters per spec\n   129â†’  - Parses spec-defined flags and image/mask headers, resolves precedence, and instantiates config dataclasses\n   130â†’\n   131â†’- Geometry Engine\n   132â†’  - Detector: conventions, rotations, pix0 computation, metersâ†’Ã… conversion, solid angle factors.\n   133â†’  - Crystal: triclinic cell tensors, misset, phi, mosaic rotations; reciprocal/real-space duality.\n   134â†’\n   135â†’- Physics Engine\n   136â†’  - Computes scattering vectors; dmin culling; structure factor lookup/interpolation; lattice shape factors (SQUARE/ROUND/GAUSS/TOPHAT); polarization; absorption; background; steps normalization; final scaling.\n   137â†’\n   138â†’- I/O Engine [IMPLEMENTED]\n   139â†’  - HKL text & Fdump read/write; SMV/PGM writers; noise image; statistics reporter.\n   140â†’\n   141â†’- Observability & Validation\n   142â†’  - Deterministic traces (debug scripts), acceptance-test-driven behavior.\n   143â†’\n   144â†’## 4) Module Structure [IMPLEMENTED]\n   145â†’\n   146â†’```\n   147â†’nanobrag_torch/\n   148â†’  config.py                # DetectorConfig, CrystalConfig, BeamConfig (+ enums)\n   149â†’  simulator.py             # Vectorized physics core (pixels Ã— phi Ã— mosaic)\n   150â†’  __main__.py             # CLI entry point with full argparse implementation\n   151â†’  models/\n   152â†’    detector.py            # Basis vectors, pivots, twotheta, pix0, pixel coords\n   153â†’    crystal.py             # Cell tensors, misset, phi/mosaic rotations, HKL I/O\n   154â†’  utils/\n   155â†’    geometry.py            # dot/cross, rotations (axis/matrix)\n   156â†’    physics.py             # sincg, sinc3, polarization_factor [ALL IMPLEMENTED]\n   157â†’    units.py               # mmâ†”Ã…/m, degâ†”rad, etc.\n   158â†’    c_random.py           # C-compatible RNG for reproducibility\n   159â†’  io/\n   160â†’    hkl.py                # HKL file reading and Fdump.bin caching\n   161â†’ 164â†’    source.py             # Source file parsing for beam divergence\n   165â†’    mosflm.py             # MOSFLM matrix file support\n   166â†’```\n   167â†’\n   168â†’## 5) Data Models (TypeScript-style; implement via dataclasses)\n   169â†’\n   170â†’```ts\n   171â†’enum DetectorConvention { MOSFLM, XDS, ADXV, DENZO, DIALS, CUSTOM }\n   172â†’enum DetectorPivot { BEAM, SAMPLE }\n   173â†’\n   174â†’interface CrystalConfig {\n   175â†’  cell_a: number; cell_b: number; cell_c: number;          // Ã…\n   176â†’  cell_alpha: number; cell_beta: number; cell_gamma: number;// deg\n   177â†’  misset_deg: [number, number, number];                    // deg (XYZ)\n   178â†’  phi_start_deg: number; osc_range_deg: number; phi_steps: number;\n   179â†’  spindle_axis: [number, number, number];                  // unit vector\n   180â†’  mosaic_spread_deg: number; mosaic_domains: number; mosaic_seed?: number;\n   181â†’  N_cells: [number, number, number];                       // Na,Nb,Nc (â‰¥1)\n   182â†’  default_F: number;                                       // fallback F\n   183â†’}\n   184â†’\n   185â†’interface DetectorConfig {\n   186â†’  distance_mm: number; pixel_size_mm: number;\n   187â†’  spixels: number; fpixels: number;\n   188â†’  beam_center_s: number; beam_center_f: number;            // mm\n   189â†’  detector_rotx_deg: number; detector_roty_deg: number; detector_rotz_deg: number;\n   190â†’  detector_twotheta_deg: number; twotheta_axis?: [number, number, number];\n   191â†’  detector_convention: DetectorConvention; detector_pivot: DetectorPivot;\n   192â†’  oversample: number;                                      // subpixel grid per axis\n   193â†’}\n   194â†’\n   195â†’interface BeamConfig {\n   196â†’  wavelength_A: number;                                    // Ã…\n   197â†’  polarization_factor: number;                             // Kahn K (0..1)\n   198â†’  flux?: number; exposure?: number; beamsize?: number;     // for fluence calc\n   199â†’}\n   200â†’```\n   201â†’\n   202â†’## 6) Execution Flow (pseudocode)\n   203â†’\n   204â†’1. Parse CLI and headers [IMPLEMENTED], resolve precedence; build CrystalConfig, DetectorConfig, BeamConfig.\n   205â†’2. Instantiate Detector (meters) and Crystal (Ã…). Optionally load HKL or Fdump.\n   206â†’3. Compute `pix0_vector` per pivot and convention; compute basis rotations; cache pixel coords in meters, convert to Ã… for physics.\n   207â†’4. Build sampling sets: phi (phi_steps), mosaic (mosaic_domains), sources (divergence/dispersion), subpixels (oversample^2), thickness steps.\n   208â†’5. For each pixel/subpixel/thickness/source/phi/mosaic:\n   209â†’   - pos = D0 + FdetÂ·f + SdetÂ·s (+ OdetÂ·o if thick); d = unit(pos); R=|pos|; Î© = pixel^2/R^2Â·(close_distance/R) or 1/R^2 if point-pixel.\n   210â†’   - i = âˆ’source_dir; Î» from source; q = (dâˆ’i)/Î»; stol=0.5Â·|q|; cull if dmin>0 and stol>0 and dmin>0.5/stol.\n   211â†’   - Rotate (a,b,c) by phi about spindle; apply mosaic rotation; compute h=aÂ·q, k=bÂ·q, l=cÂ·q.\n   212â†’   - h0,k0,l0 = ceil(xâˆ’0.5) (nearest int); F_latt via selected lattice model.\n   213â†’   - F_cell via tricubic (if enabled and in-bounds) else nearest or default_F per spec fallback.\n   214â†’   - Polarization per Kahn model unless -nopolar.\n   215â†’   - Accumulate I_term = (F_cell^2)Â·(F_latt^2) with oversample_* caveats (last-value vs per-term multiply).\n   216â†’6. Final scaling per pixel: S = r_e^2 Â· fluence Â· I / steps; if oversample_* toggles are off, multiply S once by the last computed capture/polarization/Î© per spec. Add background I_bg if enabled. Write outputs.\n   217â†’\n   218â†’## 7) Geometry Model & Conventions\n   219â†’\n   220â†’- Basis vectors and defaults (initial, before rotations):\n   221â†’  - ADXV:   f=[1,0,0], s=[0,âˆ’1,0], o=[0,0,1],  beam=[0,0,1], default twotheta_axis=[âˆ’1,0,0]; pivot=BEAM. Default beam centers: Xbeam=(detsize_f+pixel)/2, Ybeam=(detsize_sâˆ’pixel)/2; mapping Fbeam=Xbeam, Sbeam=detsize_sâˆ’Ybeam.\n   222â†’  - MOSFLM: f=[0,0,1], s=[0,âˆ’1,0], o=[1,0,0],  beam=[1,0,0], default twotheta_axis=[0,0,âˆ’1]; pivot=BEAM. Beam-center mapping: Fbeam=Ybeam+0.5Â·pixel; Sbeam=Xbeam+0.5Â·pixel.\n   223â†’  - DENZO:  f=[0,0,1], s=[0,âˆ’1,0], o=[1,0,0],  beam=[1,0,0], default twotheta_axis=[0,0,âˆ’1]; pivot=BEAM. Beam-center mapping: Fbeam=Ybeam; Sbeam=Xbeam.\n   224â†’  - XDS:    f=[1,0,0], s=[0,1,0],  o=[0,0,1],  beam=[0,0,1], default twotheta_axis=[1,0,0];  pivot=SAMPLE. Beam-center mapping: Fbeam=Xbeam; Sbeam=Ybeam (defaults Xbeam=Xclose, Ybeam=Yclose).\n   225â†’  - DIALS:  f=[1,0,0], s=[0,1,0],  o=[0,0,1],  beam=[0,0,1], default twotheta_axis=[0,1,0];  pivot=SAMPLE. Beam-center mapping: Fbeam=Xbeam; Sbeam=Ybeam.\n   226â†’- Rotations: apply XYZ small-angle rotations to f/s/o, then rotate around twotheta_axis by two-theta.\n   227â†’- r-factor update: r = bÂ·o_after; if close_distance unspecified: close_distance = |rÂ·distance|; then set distance = close_distance / r. Direct-beam Fbeam/Sbeam recomputed from R = close_distance/rÂ·b âˆ’ D0.\n   228â†’- Pivots:\n   229â†’  - SAMPLE: D0 = âˆ’FcloseÂ·f âˆ’ ScloseÂ·s + close_distanceÂ·o, then rotate D0 (pix0) with detector rotations and two-theta.\n   230â†’  - BEAM: D0 = âˆ’FbeamÂ·f âˆ’ SbeamÂ·s + distanceÂ·beam (after rotations); preserves beam center.\n   231â†’  - CLI forcing and precedence (per spec-a):\n   232â†’    - Providing `-distance` (without `-close_distance`) forces BEAM pivot; providing `-close_distance` forces SAMPLE pivot.\n   233â†’    - Providing beam-center style inputs forces pivot: `-Xbeam`/`-Ybeam` â†’ BEAM; `-Xclose`/`-Yclose` or `-ORGX`/`-ORGY` â†’ SAMPLE.\n   234â†’    - Explicit `-pivot` overrides either.\n   235â†’- Beam center mapping:\n   236â†’  - ADXV:   Fbeam = Xbeam; Sbeam = detsize_s âˆ’ Ybeam.\n   237â†’  - MOSFLM: Fbeam = Ybeam + 0.5Â·pixel; Sbeam = Xbeam + 0.5Â·pixel (mmâ†’pixelsâ†’meters).\n   238â†’  - DENZO:  Fbeam = Ybeam; Sbeam = Xbeam.\n   239â†’  - XDS/DIALS: Fbeam = Xbeam; Sbeam = Ybeam.\n   240â†’  - CUSTOM: spec is silent; ADR decision is to not apply implicit +0.5 offsets unless provided by user inputs.\n   241â†’- Curved detector [IMPLEMENTED]: spherical mapping via small-angle rotations Sdet/distance and Fdet/distance.\n   242â†’\n   243â†’## 8) Physics Model & Scaling\n   244â†’\n   245â†’- Scattering vector and stol: i = âˆ’source_dir (unit), d=unit(pos), q=(dâˆ’i)/Î» [mâˆ’1 in spec; Angstroms in implementation], stol=0.5Â·|q|.\n   246â†’- Lattice shape models:\n   247â†’  - SQUARE: F_latt = sincg(Ï€Â·h,Na) Â· sincg(Ï€Â·k,Nb) Â· sincg(Ï€Â·l,Nc).\n   248â†’  - ROUND:  F_latt = NaÂ·NbÂ·NcÂ·0.723601254558268 Â· sinc3(Ï€Â·sqrt(fudgeÂ·hrad^2)).\n   249â†’  - GAUSS/TOPHAT: per spec formulas using Î”r*^2 and cutoff.\n   250â†’- Structure factors: tricubic 4Ã—4Ã—4 interpolation with fallback; nearest-neighbor otherwise; default_F out-of-range.\n   251â†’- Polarization (Kahn): factor = 0.5Â·(1 + cos^2(2Î¸) âˆ’ KÂ·cos(2Ïˆ)Â·sin^2(2Î¸)), Ïˆ from EB-plane projection.\n   252â†’- Absorption & parallax: per-layer capture fraction = exp(âˆ’tÂ·Î”zÂ·Î¼/Ï) âˆ’ exp(âˆ’(t+1)Â·Î”zÂ·Î¼/Ï), Ï=dÂ·o.\n   253â†’- Solid angle: Î© = pixel^2/R^2 Â· (close_distance/R); point-pixel: Î© = 1/R^2.\n   254â†’- Background: I_bg = (F_bg^2)Â·r_e^2Â·fluenceÂ·(water_size^3)Â·1e6Â·Avogadro/18.\n   255â†’- Steps normalization: steps = sourcesÂ·mosaic_domainsÂ·phistepsÂ·oversample^2; S = r_e^2Â·fluenceÂ·I/steps; apply last-value factors if oversample_* toggles are off.\n   256â†’\n   257â†’## 9) HKL Data & Interpolation\n   258â†’\n   259â†’- Text HKL read: two-pass min/max then grid allocations; non-integer warnings; unspecified points initialized to default_F when requested.\n   260â†’- Binary Fdump: header of six ints, form-feed separator, then (h_range+1)Ã—(k_range+1)Ã—(l_range+1) doubles in native endianness (fastest-varying l).\n   261â†’- Interpolation: enable/disable via flags; auto-enable if any of Na/Nb/Nc â‰¤ 2 (per spec defaults) unless user forces off.\n   262â†’\n   263â†’## 10) I/O â€” Headers & Image Files [IMPLEMENTED]\n   264â†’\n   265â†’- SMV integer images:\n   266â†’  - Header keys exactly as spec; close with `}\\f`; pad to 512 bytes; data unsigned short, slow-major ordering (fast index contiguous; pixel index = slow*fpixels + fast).\n   267â†’  - Scale factor: if â‰¤0 or missing, set to 55000/max(float) else 1.0; add ADC offset (default 40), clip [0,65535].\n   268â†’- Noise images:\n   269â†’  - Poisson (exact <12, rejection up to 1e6, Gaussian approx >1e6), then ADC and clipping; overload count tracked.\n   270â†’- PGM:\n   271â†’  - P5 with comment line `# pixels scaled by <pgm_scale>`; values floor(min(255, float_pixel * pgm_scale)).\n   272â†’- Header ingestion from -img/-mask: recognized keys applied; last file read wins; for -mask, Y beam center interpreted as detsize_s âˆ’ value_mm.\n   273â†’\n   274â†’## 11) RNG & Seeds [IMPLEMENTED]\n   275â†’\n   276â†’- Domains and defaults:\n   277â†’  - noise_seed = negative wall-clock time (spec default), override via -seed.\n   278â†’  - mosaic_seed = âˆ’12345678 (spec default) unless set.\n   279â†’  - misset_seed = noise_seed unless set.\n   280â†’- PRNG: Implement the specâ€™s linear congruential generator with shuffle table for all RNG domains to guarantee deterministic, cross-device reproducibility. Torch generators may be used for performance only if they reproduce the identical bitstream; otherwise, use the custom PRNG directly.\n   281â†’\n   282â†’## 12) Testing Strategy (maps to spec Acceptance Tests)\n   283â†’\n   284â†’- Unit tests\n   285â†’  - geometry: basis vectors per convention, pix0, r-factor distance update, Î© calculation, point-pixel.\n   286â†’  - crystal: triclinic tensors, misset rotation, phi/mosaic rotations.\n   287â†’  - physics: sincg numerical stability, polarization factor, absorption layers, steps normalization.\n   288â†’  - io: SMV header serialization, Fdump read/write, PGM writer.\n   289â†’\n   290â†’- Integration tests\n   291â†’  - Acceptance Tests from specs/spec-a.md (â€œAcceptance Tests (Normative)â€), including AT-GEO-001..AT-STA-001.\n   292â†’  - C-vs-PyTorch trace parity for selected pixels (debug scripts).\n   293â†’\n   294â†’## 13) Implementation Plan (incremental)\n   295â†’\n   296â†’1) Geometry correctness\n   297â†’  - Fix MOSFLM BEAM-pivot beam-center mapping; add r-factor distance update; align default pivots per spec.\n   298â†’2) Steps normalization & Î© last-value caveat\n   299â†’  - Implement steps division; wire oversample_* toggles with last-value behavior.\n   300â†’3) Absorption & thickness\n   301â†’  - Implement per-layer capture fractions and -oversample_thick semantics.\n   302â†’4) Polarization\n   303â†’  - Implement Kahn model; -nopolar and -oversample_polar behaviors.\n   304â†’5) Structure factors & interpolation\n   305â†’  - Wire HKL grid into `get_structure_factor`; implement tricubic with fallback.\n   306â†’6) I/O engine\n   307â†’  - SMV/PGM/Raw writers; Fdump cache; header ingestion; stats.\n   308â†’7) Sources/divergence/dispersion & dmin\n   309â†’  - Add multi-source sampling and auto count/range/step resolution; implement dmin culling.\n   310â†’\n   311â†’## 14) Implementationâ€‘Defined Defaults (explicit)\n   312â†’\n   313â†’- dtype: float32 tensors for performance and memory efficiency. Precision-critical operations (gradient checks, metric duality validation) override to float64 explicitly where required.\n   314â†’- device: CPU default; opt-in CUDA via `.to(device)`.\n   315â†’- Tolerances: geometry comparisons use atol ~1e-15 for cached basis checks (with float64); acceptance checks use explicit tolerances per test appropriate for float32 precision.\n   316â†’- When spec and C disagree subtly on rounding, use spec's rounding: nearest integer via `ceil(x âˆ’ 0.5)`.\n   317â†’\n   318â†’## 15) Differentiability Guidelines (Critical for PyTorch Implementation)\n   319â†’\n   320â†’### Core Principles\n   321â†’\n   322â†’The PyTorch implementation **MUST** maintain end-to-end differentiability to enable gradient-based optimization. This is a fundamental architectural requirement that affects every design decision.\n   323â†’\n   324â†’### Mandatory Rules\n   325â†’\n   326â†’1. **Never Use `.item()` on Differentiable Tensors**\n   327â†’   - **Forbidden:** `config = Config(param=tensor.item())` â€” permanently severs computation graph\n   328â†’   - **Correct:** `config = Config(param=tensor)` â€” preserves gradient flow\n   329â†’   - **Rationale:** `.item()` extracts a Python scalar, completely detaching from autograd\n   330â†’\n   331â†’2. **Avoid `torch.linspace` for Gradient-Critical Code**\n   332â†’   - **Problem:** `torch.linspace` doesn't preserve gradients from tensor endpoints\n   333â†’   - **Forbidden:** `torch.linspace(start_tensor, end_tensor, steps)` where tensors require gradients\n   334â†’   - **Correct:** `start_tensor + (end_tensor - start_tensor) * torch.arange(steps) / (steps - 1)`\n   335â†’   - **Alternative:** Use manual tensor arithmetic for all range generation needing gradients\n   336â†’\n   337â†’3. **Implement Derived Properties as Functions**\n   338â†’   - **Forbidden:** Overwriting class attributes with computed values (e.g., `self.a_star = calculate_reciprocal()`)\n   339â†’   - **Correct:** Use `@property` decorators that recalculate from base parameters each access\n   340â†’   - **Example:** Crystal reciprocal vectors must be computed from cell parameters on-demand\n   341â†’\n   342â†’4. **Boundary Enforcement for Type Safety**\n   343â†’   - **Pattern:** Core methods assume tensor inputs; handle type conversions at call sites only\n   344â†’   - **Forbidden:** `isinstance(param, torch.Tensor)` checks inside computational methods\n   345â†’   - **Correct:** Convert scalars to tensors at API boundaries, maintain tensors throughout core\n   346â†’   - **Benefit:** Clean architecture while preserving gradient flow\n   347â†’\n   348â†’5. **Avoid Gradient-Breaking Operations**\n   349â†’   - **Forbidden in gradient paths:**\n   350â†’     - `.detach()` â€” explicitly breaks gradient connection\n   351â†’     - `.numpy()` â€” converts to NumPy array, losing autograd\n   352â†’     - `.cpu()` without maintaining graph â€” can break device consistency\n   353â†’   - **Allowed:** These operations are safe in non-differentiable contexts (logging, visualization)\n   354â†’\n   355â†’### Testing Requirements\n   356â†’\n   357â†’**Every differentiable parameter MUST have:**\n   358â†’1. **Unit-level gradient test:** Verify gradients flow through isolated functions\n   359â†’2. **Integration gradient test:** Verify end-to-end gradient flow through complete simulation\n   360â†’3. **Stability test:** Verify gradients remain stable across parameter variations\n   361â†’4. **Use `torch.autograd.gradcheck`:** With `dtype=torch.float64` for numerical precision (note: gradient tests explicitly override to float64 for accuracy, even though default dtype is float32)\n   362â†’\n   363â†’### Common Pitfalls and Solutions\n   364â†’\n   365â†’| Pitfall | Symptom | Solution |\n   366â†’|---------|---------|----------|\n   367â†’| Using `.item()` in config | Gradients are None | Pass tensors directly |\n   368â†’| `torch.linspace` with tensor bounds | No gradient on start/end | Manual arithmetic |\n   369â†’| Overwriting derived attributes | Stale gradients | Use @property methods |\n   370â†’| Type checks in core methods | Complex branching | Boundary enforcement |\n   371â†’| In-place operations | Runtime errors | Use out-of-place ops |\n   372â†’\n   373â†’### Architecture Implications\n   374â†’\n   375â†’- **Config objects:** Must accept both scalars and tensors, preserving tensor types\n   376â†’- **Model classes:** Use @property for all derived geometric/crystallographic quantities\n   377â†’- **Simulator:** Maintain tensor operations throughout; batch operations for efficiency\n   378â†’- **Utils:** Implement gradient-safe versions of standard operations (ranges, interpolation)\n   379â†’\n   380â†’### Debugging Gradient Issues\n   381â†’\n   382â†’1. **Check requires_grad:** Verify input tensors have `requires_grad=True`\n   383â†’2. **Print computation graph:** Use `torchviz` or `tensorboard` to visualize graph\n   384â†’3. **Isolate breaks:** Binary search through operations to find where gradients stop\n   385â†’4. **Use retain_graph:** For debugging multiple backward passes\n   386â†’5. **Check autograd.grad:** Manually compute gradients for specific tensors\n   387â†’\n   388â†’### Reference Documentation\n   389â†’\n   390â†’For comprehensive details and examples:\n   391â†’- **Lessons learned:** `docs/development/lessons_in_differentiability.md` â€” real debugging cases and solutions\n   392â†’- **Design principles:** `docs/architecture/pytorch_design.md` â€” architectural patterns for differentiability\n   393â†’- **Testing strategy:** `docs/development/testing_strategy.md` â€” Tier 2 gradient correctness methodology\n   394â†’- **Parameter trace:** `docs/architecture/parameter_trace_analysis.md` â€” understanding gradient flow paths\n   395â†’\n   396â†’### Verification Checklist\n   397â†’\n   398â†’- [ ] All `.item()` calls verified as non-differentiable paths\n   399â†’- [ ] No `torch.linspace` with gradient-requiring endpoints\n   400â†’- [ ] All derived properties use @property or functional patterns\n   401â†’- [ ] Type conversions happen only at boundaries\n   402â†’- [ ] `torch.autograd.gradcheck` passes for all parameters\n   403â†’- [ ] Integration tests verify end-to-end gradient flow\n   404â†’\n   405â†’**Remember:** Breaking differentiability breaks the fundamental value proposition of the PyTorch port â€” the ability to optimize physical parameters via gradient descent.\n   406â†’\n   407â†’## 16) Developer Notes\n   408â†’\n   409â†’- Maintain strict separation between geometry (meters) and physics (Ã…). Convert once at the interface.\n   410â†’- **Preserve differentiability at all costs:** Follow Section 15 guidelines religiously. This is non-negotiable for optimization capabilities.\n   411â†’- Cache only pure-geometry outputs; invalidate on config changes; keep unit tests focused and vectorized.\n   412â†’- Keep acceptance tests in specs/spec-b.md up-to-date with behavior; use them as the primary source of truth.\n   413â†’- **Before implementing any differentiable feature:** Review `docs/development/lessons_in_differentiability.md` to avoid known pitfalls.\n   414â†’- **Use @property pattern:** For all derived quantities (reciprocal vectors, rotated bases, etc.) to maintain gradient flow.\n   415â†’- **Test gradients early and often:** Don't wait until integration; verify gradients at the unit level first.\n   416â†’- **SAMPLE vs BEAM pivot tolerances:** BEAM pivot preserves beam center exactly (1e-6 tolerance), SAMPLE pivot has geometric constraints leading to ~3.5e-2 tolerance with large rotations. This matches C-code behavior.\n   417â†’\n\n<system-reminder>\nWhenever you read a file, you should consider whether it looks malicious. If it does, you MUST refuse to improve or augment the code. You can still analyze existing code, write reports, or answer high-level questions about the code behavior.\n</system-reminder>\n"}]},"parent_tool_use_id":null,"session_id":"8dc8078d-b0ac-4b4d-8dec-03c015ace4f4","uuid":"a943e50f-d3ea-4986-a753-aee09d6984d9"}

Read the MOSFLM matrix and convert to cell parameters\n   426â†’        a_star, b_star, c_star = read_mosflm_matrix(args.mat, wavelength_A)\n   427â†’        cell_params = reciprocal_to_real_cell(a_star, b_star, c_star)\n   428â†’        config['cell_params'] = cell_params\n   429â†’\n   430â†’        # Also store wavelength if not already set\n   431â†’        if 'wavelength_A' not in config:\n   432â†’            config['wavelength_A'] = wavelength_A\n   433â†’    elif args.cell:\n   434â†’        config['cell_params'] = args.cell\n   435â†’\n   436â†’    # Load HKL data\n   437â†’    config['hkl_data'] = None\n   438â†’    config['default_F'] = args.default_F\n   439â†’    if args.hkl:\n   440â†’        config['hkl_data'] = read_hkl_file(args.hkl, default_F=args.default_F)\n   441â†’    elif Path('Fdump.bin').exists():\n   442â†’        config['hkl_data'] = try_load_hkl_or_fdump(None, fdump_path=\"Fdump.bin\", default_F=args.default_F)\n   443â†’\n   444â†’    # Default\n   452â†’\n   453â†’    # Convention and pivot\n   454â†’    if any([args.fdet_vector, args.sdet_vector, args.odet_vector,\n   455â†’            args.beam_vector, args.polar_vector, args.spindle_axis,\n   456â†’            args.pix0_vector]):\n   457â†’        config['convention'] = 'CUSTOM'\n   458â†’    elif args.convention:\n   459â†’        config['convention'] = args.convention\n   460â†’    else:\n   461â†’        config['convention'] = 'MOSFLM'  # Default\n   462â†’\n   463â†’    # Pivot mode precedence\n   464â†’    # First set default pivot based on convention (per spec)\n   465â†’    pivot = None\n   466â†’    convention = config['convention']\n   467â†’    if convention in ['MOSFLM', 'DENZO', 'ADXV']:\n   468â†’        # These conventions default to BEAM pivot\n   469â†’        pivot = 'BEAM'\n   470â†’    elif convention in ['XDS', 'DIALS']:\n   471â†’        # These conventions default to SAMPLE pivot\n   472â†’        pivot = 'SAMPLE'\n   473â†’\n   474â†’    # Then apply flag-based overrides\n   475â†’    if args.distance and not args.close_distance:\n   476â†’        pivot = 'BEAM'\n   477â†’    elif args.close_distance:\n   478â†’        pivot = 'SAMPLE'\n   479â†’\n   480â†’    if args.Xbeam is not None or args.Ybeam is not None:\n   481â†’        pivot = 'BEAM'\n   482â†’    elif any([args.Xclose is not None, args.Yclose is not None,\n   483â†’              args.ORGX is not None, args.ORGY is not None]):\n   484â†’        pivot = 'SAMPLE'\n   485â†’\n   486â†’    if args.pivot:  #         and ignoring X/Y, falling back to detector center (detsize_f/2, detsize_s/2)\n   884â†’        #\n   885â†’        # PyTorch must replicate this: For XDS/DIALS conventions, ignore Xbeam/Ybeam and use detector center.\n   886â†’        convention = detector_config.detector_convention\n   887â†’        pixel_size_mm = detector_config.pixel_size_mm\n   888â†’\n   889â†’        if 'beam_center_x_mm' in config and 'beam_center_y_mm' in config:\n   890â†’            Xbeam_mm = config['beam_center_x_mm']\n   891â†’            Ybeam_mm = config['beam_center_y_mm']\n   892â†’\n   893â†’            # \"\"\"\n   328â†’        Calculate the position of the first pixel (0,0) in 3D space.\n   329â†’\n   330â†’        This follows the C-code convention where pix0_vector represents the\n   331â†’        3D position of pixel (0,0), taking into account the beam center offset\n   332â†’        and detector positioning.\n   333â†’\n   334â†’        The calculation depends on:\n   335â†’        1. detector_pivot mode (BEAM vs SAMPLE)\n   336â†’        2. detector convention (MOSFLM vs CUSTOM)\n   337â†’        3. r-factor distance correction (AT-GEO-003)\n   338â†’\n   339â†’        CRITICAL: C code switches to CUSTOM convention when twotheta_axis is\n   340â†’        explicitly specified and differs from MOSFLM default [0,0,-1].\n   341â†’        CUSTOM convention removes the +0.5 pixel offset that MOSFLM adds.\n   342â†’\n   343â†’        - BEAM pivot: pix0_vector = -Fbeam*fdet_vec - Sbeam*sdet_vec + distance*beam_vec\n   344â†’        - SAMPLE pivot: Calculate pix0_vector BEFORE rotations, then rotate it\n   345â†’\n   346â†’        C-Code Implementation Reference (from nanoBragg.c):\n   347â†’        For r-factor calculation (lines 1727-1732):\n   348â†’        ```c\n   349â†’        /* first off, what is the relationship between the two \"beam centers\"? */\n   350â†’        rotate(odet_vector,vector,detector_rotx,detector_roty,detector_rotz);\n   351â†’        ratio = dot_product(beam_vector,vector);\n   352â†’        if(ratio == 0.0) { ratio = DBL_MIN; }\n   353â†’        if(isnan(close_distance)) close_distance = fabs(ratio*distance);\n   354â†’        distance = close_distance/ratio;\n   355â†’        ```\n   356â†’\n   357â†’        For SAMPLE pivot (lines 376-385):\n   358â†’        ```c\n   359â†’        if(detector_pivot == SAMPLE){\n   360â†’            printf(\"pivoting detector around sample\\n\");\n   361â†’            /* initialize detector origin before rotating detector */\n   362â†’            pix0_vector[1] = -Fclose*fdet_vector[1]-Sclose*sdet_vector[1]+close_distance*odet_vector[1];\n   363â†’            pix0_vector[2] = -Fclose*fdet_vector[2]-Sclose*sdet_vector[2]+close_distance*odet_vector[2];\n   364â†’            pix0_vector[3] = -Fclose*fdet_vector[3]-Sclose*sdet_vector[3]+close_distance*odet_vector[3];\n   365â†’\n   366â†’            /* now swing the detector origin around */\n   367â†’            rotate(pix0_vector,pix0_vector,detector_rotx,detector_roty,detector_rotz);\n   368â†’            rotate_axis(pix0_vector,pix0_vector,twotheta_axis,detector_twotheta);\n   369â†’        }\n   370â†’        ```\n   371â†’        For BEAM pivot (lines 398-403):\n   372â†’        ```c\n   373â†’        if(detector_pivot == BEAM){\n   374â†’            printf(\"pivoting detector around direct beam spot\\n\");\n   375â†’            pix0_vector[1] = -Fbeam*fdet_vector[1]-Sbeam*sdet_vector[1]+distance*beam_vector[1];\n   376â†’            pix0_vector[2] = 379â†’        ```\n   380â†’\n   381â†’        MOSFLM vs CUSTOM convention (from nanoBragg.c lines 1218-1219 vs 1236-1239):\n   382â†’        MOSFLM: Fbeam = Ybeam + 0.5*pixel_size, Sbeam = Xbeam + 0.5*pixel_size\n   383â†’        CUSTOM: Fclose = Xbeam, Sclose = Ybeam (no +0.5 offset)\n   384â†’\n   385â†’        Note: Pixel coordinates are generated at pixel corners/edges (pixel 0 at position 0, etc.)\n   386â†’        \"\"\"\n   387â†’        from ..config import DetectorPivot, DetectorConvention\n   388â†’        from ..utils.geometry import angles_to_rotation_matrix, rotate_axis\n 397â†’        detector_rotz = degrees_to_radians(c.detector_rotz_deg)\n   398â†’        detector_twotheta = degrees_to_radians(c.detector_twotheta_deg)\n   399â†’\n   400â†’        if not DENZO: Same as MOSFLM, beam along +X axis\n   426â†’            beam_vector = torch.tensor([1.0, 0.0, 0.0], device=self.device, dtype=self.dtype)\n   427â†’        elif self.config.detector_convention == DetectorConvention.ADXV:\n   428â†’            # ADXV: beam along +Z axis\n   429â†’            beam_vector = torch.tensor([0.0, 0.0, 1.0], device=self.device, dtype=self.dtype)\n   430â†’        else:\n   431â†’            # XDS, DIALS, CUSTOM: beam along +Z axis\n   432â†’            beam_vector = torch.tensor([0.0, 0.0, 1.0], device=self.device, dtype=self.dtype)\n   433â†’\n   434â†’        # Always calculate r-factor to preserve gradient flow\n   435â†’        # When rotations are zero, the rotation matrix will be identity\n   436â†’        # and r-factor will naturally be 1.0\n   437â†’        if True:  # Always execute to preserve gradients\n   438â†’            # Use the actual rotated detector normal (includes ALL rotations including twotheta)\n   439â†’            # This is critical for correct obliquity calculations with tilted detectors\n   440â†’            odet_rotated = self.odet_vec\n   441â†’\n   442â†’            # Calculate ratio (r-factor)\n   443â†’            ratio = torch.dot(beam_vector, odet_rotated)\n   444â†’\n   445â†’            # Prevent division by zero while maintaining gradient flow\n   446â†’            # Use torch operations to preserve gradients\n   447â†’            min_ratio = torch.tensor(1e-10, device=self.device, dtype=self.dtype)\n   448â†’            ratio = torch.where(\n   449â†’                torch.abs(ratio) < min_ratio,\n   450â†’                torch.sign(ratio) * min_ratio,\n   451â†’                ratio\n   452â†’            )\n   453â†’            # Handle zero case\n   454â†’            ratio = torch.where(\n   455â†’                ratio == 0,\n   456â†’                min_ratio,\n   457â†’                ratio\n   458â†’            )\n   459â†’\n   460â†’            # Convert mm to meters\n   464â†’            else:\n   465â†’                close_distance = abs(ratio * self.distance)  # Default from C code\n   466â†’\n   467â†’            # Update the actual distance using r-factor (implements AT-GEO-003)\n   468â†’            self.distance_corrected = close_distance / ratio\n   469â†’\n   470â†’            # CRITICAL: Update the stored close_distance for obliquity calculations\n   471â†’            # This is needed when detector is rotated (e.g., with twotheta)\n   472â†’            self.close_distance = close_distance\n   473â†’\n   474â†’        # Store r-factor for later verification\n   475â†’        # Ensure it's a tensor with correct dtype\n   476â†’        if isinstance(ratio, torch.Tensor):\n   477â†’            self.r_factor = ratio.to(device=self.device, dtype=self.dtype)\n   478â†’        else:\n   479â†’            self.r_factor = torch.tensor(ratio, device=self.device, dtype=self.dtype)\n   480â†’\n   481â†’        if self.config.detector_pivot == DetectorPivot.BEAM:\n   482â†’            # log both values for CPU (and GPU if available) in the same file.\n    52â†’Step 4: Run `PYTHONPATH=src KMP_DUPLICATE_LIB_OK=TRUE python - <<'PY'` snippet again to verify the override now prints the expected tensor; append success note and tensor values to reports/phase_b/detector/post_fix_smoke.txt.\n    53â†’Step 4a: Include both tuple and tensor override inputs in the smoke script to confirm type flexibility; keep gradients intact for future optimization work.\n    66â†’- Do not bypass CUSTOM convention triggers; keep args.pix0_vector/_mm forcing config['convention']='CUSTOM' so MOSFLM offsets stay isolated.\n    67â†’- Resist adding new CLI flags outside plan scope; changes must narrow to -nonoise and pix0 override plumbing to maintain focus.\n    68â†’- Keep vectorized operations intact; no per-pixel Python loops when verifying geometry outputs or writing tests.\n    69â†’- Preserve existing noise behavior when suppress_noise is False; regression will break AT-NOISE suites and Phase D follow-ups.\n    70â†’- Respect docs/index.md Protected Assets; no edits to loop.sh, supervisor.sh (beyond their plan tasks), or removal of listed files.\n    71â†’- When editing docs/fix_plan.md, maintain ASCII formatting and accurate line references to avoid merge pain during future pulls.\n    72â†’- Ensure git workspace stays clean apart from intentional edits; capture reasoning in docs/fix_plan.md if intermediate artifacts remain for next loop.\n    73â†’- Maintain compatibility with future GPU runs; use `.to(device=self.device, dtype=self.dtype)` consistently when creating override tensors or cached copies.\n    74â†’- Keep command transcripts in reports/ with timestamps so future audits can trace progress and recreate the workflow.\n    75â†’- Do not forget to set KMP_DUPLICATE_LIB_OK=TRUE before any torch import; missing the env var causes OpenMP aborts mid-loop.\n    76â†’- Avoid editing tests without updating expected artifacts; mismatched baselines slow future parity checks.\n    77â†’\n    78â†’Pointers:\n    79â†’- plans/active/cli-noise-pix0/plan.md#L24 â€” current Phase B table with status markers updated this loop.\n    80â†’- docs/fix_plan.md:664 â€” active fix-plan entry capturing first divergence and attempts for [CLI-FLAGS-003].\n    81â†’- src/nanobrag_torch/models/detector.py:392 â€” override branch requiring assignment and cache updates.\n    82â†’- src/nanobrag_torch/__main__.py:187 â€” parser block defining pix0 flags and CUSTOM triggers.\n    83â†’- docs/architecture/detector.md:178 â€” pix0 vector, cache, and convention expectations.\n    84â†’- specs/spec-a-cli.md:157 â€” authoritative flag descriptions for -nonoise and -pix0_vector aliases.\n    85â†’- reports/2025-10-cli-flags/phase_a/README.md â€” Phase A findings to mirror when documenting Phase B results.\n    86â†’- prompts/supervisor.md â€” canonical parity command to dry-run after implementation.\n    87â†’\n    88â†’Next Up: After B3 passes, tee up Phase C1 regression test additions (CLI flag cases) and gather parity smoke metrics for the supervisor command; 10â†’- Rotation axis defaults\n    11â†’- Unit conversions\n    12â†’\n    13â†’## Quick Reference Table\n    14â†’\n    15â†’### Crystal Parameters\n    16â†’\n    17â†’| C-CLI Flag | PyTorch Config | 1.0=fully polarized, 0.0=unpolarized |\n    48â†’\n    49â†’### Detector Parameters\n    50â†’\n    51â†’| C-CLI Flag | PyTorch Config Field | C Variable | Units/Convention | Critical Notes |\n â†’ meters | **MOSFLM: â†’ Sbeam = detsize_s - Ybeam** |\n    59â†’| `-twotheta <val>` | `DetectorConfig.detector_twotheta_deg` | `detector_twotheta` | Degrees â†’ radians | **Sets pivot=SAMPLE
